title: Tiny Printer
post:
In 2012 a company called BERG introduced a facinating little device called the Little Printer. It was a cute little printer that you could control with your phone and print off a variety of fun gimmicky things like sudoku, news headlines, weather reports etc.
The interesting thing was that this was basically just a POS receipt printer (thermal printer) that was repurposed and made into something cool and geeky.
Unfortunately BERG went under a couple of years later and the cloud service that powered the device went with it. People were then left with useless little printers that didn’t do anything.
I really wanted one at the time, but $259 for something that I knew was a $50 piece of hardware (at most) seemed crazy, even for me.
Fast forward…
I’m writing this blog post mainly as a way of documenting my steps to producing something comparable to the Little Printer. My hope is that I can produce some software that can be used to power some potentially modified software so that I can bring the Tiny Printer to the masses. 
I thought it might be interesting to write down the iterations and ideas that I have along the way, and to share the stumbling blocks and possible solutions as I go, in case anyone wants to help out with this project, or is just interested in the process.
Wish me luck!

title: Touch Screen Mirror
short_description:
I’ve seen a few examples of smart mirrors over the past year or so.

post:
I’ve seen a few examples of smart mirrors over the past year or so. 
I really wanted a way of viewing information from my home (temperature, power usage etc), and also the ability to control a few things without having to use Alexa or automations - such as setting the alarm.

title: 3D Printing R2D2
short_description:
Is it possible to 3D print a lifesize R2D2, with motors, lights and lots of cool features?
Let's find out!

post.post:
Some of you may have seen my 3D printed Mandalorian Rifle; it was really good fun to build and was one of the first model's i've printed that actually looks realistic. 3D prints need a lot of post processing in order to get them looking good.
So now it's time for a new challenge. I came across the Astromech forum, where people have been building lifesize R2D2's and other droids. I figure it's worth a try!

I've got an Ender 3 v2 printer, which is amazing. It's an entry-level printer, but the prints I get from it are fab. It's print bed is only 220x220mm though, so R2 needs to be printed in small sections and then glued together. I'm printing him in PLA+, which is supposed to be both stronger, and more flexible than standard PLA. So far, the results are good. I get good ahesion to the bed and minimal warping. 
Printing the Dome took the best part of two weeks, printing small sections at a time. Once it was all printed I glued the outer dome using two part epoxy.
 Then it's time to sand...
